title: Text
body: Design thinking requires us to take a walk in someone else's shoes. Whether it be following on from our challenge of designing the best first day of school or working on another problem, it's important to speak to different people about their experiences and gather their insights.

title: Text
body: You’ve been a great mini-Einstein so far and worked hard on understanding the problem before you solve it. Now that we know the world can be better, we need to do something about it!

title: Text
body:
Together we will have fun learning how to 'get to the point' by:

  • practising how to create ‘How might we…?’ (HMW) questions
  • getting clear on a great challenge worth designing a solution for
  • focusing on things that are ‘unGoogleable’.

_items.backBody:
• copy and paste
  • easily answered
  • requires one source of information
  • low level answers
  • closed questions
  • only one answer.

• requires interpretation and judgement
  • makes you think!
  • can't be easily answered on an internet search engine
  • open ended.

frontImage.alt: define title card

_items.backBody:
This stage involves:

  • getting to the point
  • understanding and identifying the problem.

frontImage.alt: ideate title card

_items.backBody:
This stage focuses on:

  • solving the problem
  • coming up with ideas.

frontImage.alt: test title card

_items.backBody:
This stage involves:

  • giving it a go
  • knowing what works and making your ideas better.

title: Fill in the Blanks
textBlock:
Designers are everywhere. They aren't just working on fashion or houses, but they are in every workplace solving all sorts of %?%. Designers are always considering a range of points of view too. They spend their days understanding, trying out ideas and tinkering until they are happy that their solution is a win for lots of people.

They use their:

  • %?% to connect with people
  • %?% to think of clever ideas to make life better for those people
  • %?% to create models and test out those ideas.

Thinking like a designer, or design thinking, is a way of viewing the %?%. It's like a handy tool for solving problems. Once you know how to use design thinking, you can use it over and over again to solve problems, big and small.

_feedback.correct: Well done! What a fantastic start to learning about design thinking!

_incorrect.notFinal: Not quite! Read through the text again and then have another go. You can also watch the animation again for some more hints.

_partlyCorrect.final: Not quite! Read through the text again and then have another go. You can also watch the animation again for some more hints.
_partlyCorrect.notFinal: Not quite! Read through the text again and then have another go. You can also watch the animation again for some more hints.

title: Text
body:
The five steps of design thinking can be used in different ways, however, they usually appear in a particular order. This is the same order that was shown in the animation that you just watched.

Drag and drop the images to show this order.

_events.text: We are going to think like designers and make the first day of school the best day of school for everyone!
Up next, we get curious and caring as we build our empathy muscle. Keep thinking like a designer and look for great examples and inventions in the meantime.

title: Text
body: Read through the text and type or select the missing words.

_events.text: Hi, Dee here again! In this stage you are going to observe, engage and immerse yourself in another person's experience and develop an understanding of problems that are not your own.
Design thinking is also a muscle you strengthen through doing. This means that you can grow your heart through empathy the more you use this skill.
Use your design folio to sketch or record what the people impacted by that problem might see, hear, think, do, say and feel.

Up next, we get really clear on defining our problem. Don’t worry, if you define the problem and feel like you need to understand the people behind it even further, you can always come back to this stage!

title: Learning intentions
body:
Through building empathy and caring about our problem, together we will:

  • see a range of perspectives different to our own
  • ask questions to gain insights
  • practice understanding.

_events.text: Now you have a problem worth solving. A rule for coming up with solutions is more than one idea is a fun idea!

title: Fill in the Blanks
textBlock:
Ideate is a word made up by %?%. It's the process of coming up with %?%, and lots of them!

Designers love to have lots of problems to solve and lots of %?% to play with. They collect them, tinker with them, but more importantly, they hold them lightly. Designers don't get attached to ideas, they fall in love with real solutions with real impact.

Ideation is where we %?%, develop and express ideas for solutions to the problem we just defined.

The aim is to generate lots of ideas. These can go in lots of different directions as you build on each other's efforts. Crazy ideas are welcome and it's important to suspend all judgement and be really inclusive.

_feedback.correct: Fantastic! Let's see how you can apply this knowledge throughout this stage of the design thinking process.

_incorrect.final: Not quite! Read through the text again and then have another go. You can also watch the animation again for some more hints.
_incorrect.notFinal: Not quite! Read through the text again and then have another go. You can also watch the animation again for some more hints.

_partlyCorrect.final: Not quite! Read through the text again and then have another go. You can also watch the animation again for some more hints.
_partlyCorrect.notFinal: Not quite! Read through the text again and then have another go. You can also watch the animation again for some more hints.

title: Text
body: Read through the text and type in the missing words.

_events.text: Coming up with ideas is not as simple as you think. Let’s test this with our HMW question: How might we assist new people to our school to design their own great first day?

title: Text
body: The rules below are used by designers to come up with ideas. They can be used over and over again. Select each of the images below to reveal these rules.

frontImage.alt: bouncy ball

_items.backBody:
Throw ideas around and build on others' ideas.

One designer might say, “Let’s give everyone their own map."

Another designer might reply, “Yes and… let’s think about being more sustainable by having map points set up around the school on touch pad devices.”

frontImage.alt: dog wearing sunglasses

_items.backBody:
Weird, whacky and wonderful are all welcome!

Think:

  • Why don’t we give everyone a scooter to ride around the school?
  • A 3D video of the school grounds can be airdropped to their phone!

frontImage.alt: group of four teenagers showing different ways to try or experiement with new ideas. One is holding a new dress desing, one is pulling up his sleeves ready to try something new, one has a clipboard to record notes, and one is engaged in a virtual reality activity.

_items.backBody:
Coming up with ideas is fun and all ideas and designs are welcome.

Watch out for blocking language, such as: 

  • “We’ve tried that!”
  • “That won’t work!”

Go with the flow and give your ideas freely.

_events.text: You will need to remember the four ideation rules for coming up with ideas for this next activity. Build on others' ideas by saying "Yes, and..."

title: Text
body:
Through learning and experiencing how to come up with ideas, together we will:

  • explore lots of perspectives
  • be solutions focused
  • develop skills to help us come up with lots of solutions.

title: Text
body: You should have LOTS of ideas to turn into solutions. We now need to decide on which one to move forward with.

_events.text: Rate yourself against how well you were able to use the four ideation rules. Remember, the more you use the rules, the better you will get at using them.

_feedback.correct: Nice work! Having lots of ideas to solve your question is super helpful.

_incorrect.final: Keep practising! The more you use this ideation rule, the better you should get.
_incorrect.notFinal: Keep practising! The more you use this ideation rule, the better you should get.

_partlyCorrect.final: Keep practising! The more you use this ideation rule, the better you should get.
_partlyCorrect.notFinal: Keep practising! The more you use this ideation rule, the better you should get.

_feedback.correct: Awesome! The best ideas are weird, whacky and wonderful!

_incorrect.final: Keep practising! The more you use this ideation rule, the better you should get.
_incorrect.notFinal: Keep practising! The more you use this ideation rule, the better you should get.

_partlyCorrect.final: Keep practising! The more you use this ideation rule, the better you should get.
_partlyCorrect.notFinal: Keep practising! The more you use this ideation rule, the better you should get.

_feedback.correct: Fantastic! It's great to be able to build on the ideas of others'!

_incorrect.final: Keep practising! The more you use this ideation rule, the better you should get.
_incorrect.notFinal: Keep practising! The more you use this ideation rule, the better you should get.

_partlyCorrect.final: Keep practising! The more you use this ideation rule, the better you should get.
_partlyCorrect.notFinal: Keep practising! The more you use this ideation rule, the better you should get.

_feedback.correct: Awesome! Being able to give your ideas freely is so important in this stage.

_incorrect.final: Keep practising! The more you use this ideation rule, the better you should get.
_incorrect.notFinal: Keep practising! The more you use this ideation rule, the better you should get.

_partlyCorrect.final: Keep practising! The more you use this ideation rule, the better you should get.
_partlyCorrect.notFinal: Keep practising! The more you use this ideation rule, the better you should get.

_events.text: Up next, we activate all of our design senses: head, heart and hands. This will help us to get our ideas out of our head and then seek feedback from others.
Now you have three ideas and some amazing new skills in coming up with ideas! Remember that you can do ANYTHING but you can’t do everything.
Remember that the image above is a reminder to use your design folio. Click on the image to reveal the task.

title: Text
body:
Your class will learn more about design thinking through doing. You might choose to work on our challenge (designing the best first day of school) or you may choose to work on your own design problem. Trust the process and enjoy the journey!

You’re a designer now, so you are always looking to push your:

  • learning
  • creativity
  • collaboration.

_events.text: Let’s get smart and get to the point! What is the problem we are really trying to solve?

title: Fill in the Blanks
textBlock:
We are now getting to the part where we activate our head, as well as our %?%. Lots of ideas don't go to plan because people don't spend time understanding why something is a %?% in the first place.

By defining problems properly, you make them easier to solve. This means saving:

  • %?%
  • %?%
  • %?%.

The trick to getting really clear on %?% a problem is to remember this rule: We are tough on problems, and kind to the people who are trying to %?% them.

_feedback.correct: Fantastic effort! Let's see how you can apply this knowledge to this stage of the design thinking process.

_incorrect.final: Not quite! Read through the text again and then have another go. You can also watch the animation again for some more hints.
_incorrect.notFinal: Not quite! Read through the text again and then have another go. You can also watch the animation again for some more hints.

_partlyCorrect.final: Not quite! Read through the text again and then have another go. You can also watch the animation again for some more hints.
_partlyCorrect.notFinal: Not quite! Read through the text again and then have another go. You can also watch the animation again for some more hints.

_events.text: There are many ways you can get clear on a problem but you have to be really tough on it. Let’s both be coaches. We have to make this problem sweat and struggle in order to get challenge-fit.

Remember the five whys activity we did to help you build empathy? We are going to apply the same skills to get clarity on a problem by pretending to be detectives trying to solve a crime. Are you ready?
As a quick check in, you should test if your problem has the potential to have lots of solutions. This is how we, as designers, know that we’ve really gotten to the heart of something worth solving.
It's crunch time! Time to decide on your final question.
In the next stage, I’m going to teach you how to come up with lots of solutions to great unGoogleable questions like yours. Get your sticky notes ready, you’re going to need lots of them!
Don’t tell me, show me! We’re about to make that great idea come to life through making, tinkering and trying. The idea is to move beyond explaining.

title: Text
body:
Through building empathy and caring about our problem, together we will:

  • develop skills in tinkering and creativity
  • learn how to give and receive feedback
  • communicate our idea with others.

_events.text: Making models isn’t about just making something small. Some prototypes are life-sized!
We are now going to take our idea out into the 'real world'.

title: Fill in the Blanks
textBlock:
When you prototype, you think with your %?% or you make to think. This stage is all about %?% as you are looking for the best solution to each of the problems you have found.

In the prototype stage you take your most popular solution from your work in the %?% stage and explore it by building models or expressing your idea in a more tangible, real way other than just words. Keep your prototypes %?%.

Expect to fail quickly and often so that you can try different options without committing to one idea. The prototype stage is a chance to:

  • %?% with users
  • get new %?%
  • prepare to %?% your solutions.

_feedback.correct: Terrific job! Let's see how you can apply this knowledge as you get stuck into prototyping.

_incorrect.final: Not quite! Read through the text again and then have another go. You can also watch the animation again for some more hints.
_incorrect.notFinal: Not quite! Read through the text again and then have another go. You can also watch the animation again for some more hints.

_partlyCorrect.final: Not quite! Read through the text again and then have another go. You can also watch the animation again for some more hints.
_partlyCorrect.notFinal: Not quite! Read through the text again and then have another go. You can also watch the animation again for some more hints.

title: Text
body:
Harley Earl, a vehicle stylist, started prototyping cars using clay to sculpt models of vehicles. He did this in order to help his clients, which included movie stars, millionaires and executives, get a feel for a proposed design in a way that sketches and diagrams simply couldn’t communicate. He was doing this as early as 1927.

Watch BMW Z4 Designer's Perspective (YouTube 2:18) to see how this process of prototyping is still used today.

title: Text
body: There are so many ways you can prototype. Use whatever is available to you and keep it cheap!

title: Examples of ways you can prototype
displayTitle: Examples of ways you can prototype

_items.title: Draw it!
_items.body: Sketch out simple drawings or mind maps of your solution. This helps to ensure that it doesn’t only live in your mind but you can share these ideas with your friends and others for further discussion and ideation.

_graphic.alt: Person at an easel sketching a design.

_items.title: Tell a story!
_items.body:
Storyboarding is an excellent way of guiding people through an experience you want to create.

Think of each step of the process or journey and make this one square of your storyboard.

You can get feedback on one or more of the steps of the process to make your solution stronger.

_graphic.alt: a storyboard example comprising of four images which, when viewed together, tell a story.

_items.title: Build it!
_items.body:
Use Lego or blocks to show your idea.

The best part about using Lego to build your prototypes is that the pieces are easy to dismantle and tweak. Simply detach a part of your Lego prototype, swap it with an alternative design, and play with it to see if it works.

_graphic.alt: Lego pieces joined together on top of each other.

_items.title: Act it out!
_items.body:
Role play allows you to play with scenarios.

Be sure to use props and remember that you are trying to feel the emotion of the person you are solving the problem for.

_graphic.alt: Three teenage characters discussing an idea, with one holding a chart with information to support the conversation.

_items.title: Mock it up!
_items.body:
Like our friends in the car industry, maybe you can make a life-sized rough version of your idea.

In fashion, they might make a skirt pattern out of paper rather than fabric, or cut out a pattern and sticky tape it together.

_graphic.alt: girl using scissors to cut out a design on paper

title: The Five Whys
body:
Thinking back to our ideas for making the best first day of school, we might decide to:

  • give every new student a backpack full of things they might like or need to be a self-guided explorer
  • grab an old backpack and a bunch of items to test the weight or comfort and ask for feedback on the types of items, such as what’s missing, what’s useful or useless
  • come up with a completely different idea!

_events.text: When you prototype, you’re looking for what works. When you test, you’re looking for where your solution fails.

title: Fill in the Blanks
textBlock:
The test stage is where you go into more depth developing a %?%.

Testing gives you more %?%, insights and %?% to %?% solutions and learn more about the people you are solving problems for.

Testing and prototyping go hand-in hand. You cycle between them both, sometimes at the same time!

Every failure is an opportunity to %?% your design, so you can go back to %?% and try again.

_feedback.correct: Awesome work! Apply this knowledge as you work through this stage of the design thinking process.

_incorrect.final: Not quite! Read through the text again and then have another go. You can also watch the animation again for some more hints.
_incorrect.notFinal: Not quite! Read through the text again and then have another go. You can also watch the animation again for some more hints.

_partlyCorrect.final: Not quite! Read through the text again and then have another go. You can also watch the animation again for some more hints.
_partlyCorrect.notFinal: Not quite! Read through the text again and then have another go. You can also watch the animation again for some more hints.

title: Text
body:
Through building empathy and caring about our problem, together we will:

  • see what failure is and learn from it
  • be ready to try again or celebrate success
  • develop skills in communication.

_events.text: So many brands and companies you know of tested their way to success. They prototyped and tested with real ideas, real products and with real people. Sometimes it’s an overnight success, sometimes it’s the big fails that lead to success.

title: Text
body:
Netflix initially operated a mail-order service through which customers could order DVDs to rent that were sent directly to their homes.

As demands for digital content grew, Netflix not only began offering access to movies and TV shows online, it also began producing its own original programming ensuring the company didn’t become redundant, like DVDs!

title: My pitch
body:
Pitching is a really important part of a designer’s skill set as they need to get people using the solution or get some resources to make their idea even better.

Telling the story of your solution is almost as important as the solution itself.

_events.text: Check out the original ad for Netflix. It’s come a long way in design and product because they are always testing.
Communicating your idea is a really important skill set. Here are the tried and tested Six C’s of communicating like a pro!
It's time to practising pitching! Remember to use the Six C's as these will certainly help you with this step.

title: My pitch is clear
body:
• Take out the big words and confusing information
  • Everyone should get it.

_feedback.correct: Awesome! Clarity is super important when talking to an audience.

_incorrect.final: Keep working on it. Remember to take out the big words and keep it simple.
_incorrect.notFinal: Keep working on it. Remember to take out the big words and keep it simple.

_partlyCorrect.final: Keep working on it. Remember to take out the big words and keep it simple.
_partlyCorrect.notFinal: Keep working on it. Remember to take out the big words and keep it simple.

title: My pitch is conversational
body:
• Just have a chat
  • The best way to convince others is not to throw ideas at them but invite them into your idea.

_feedback.correct: Awesome! Seems like you have nailed this!

_incorrect.final: Keep refining your pitch. Remember to just have a chat!
_incorrect.notFinal: Keep refining your pitch. Remember to just have a chat!

_partlyCorrect.final: Keep refining your pitch. Remember to just have a chat!
_partlyCorrect.notFinal: Keep refining your pitch. Remember to just have a chat!

title: My pitch has a closure
body:
• Think about what you want them to do with this idea, information or story
  • Ask away!

_feedback.correct: Awesome! A great closure is the perfect ending to your pitch.

_incorrect.final: Keep refining your pitch until you have a powerful closure.
_incorrect.notFinal: Keep refining your pitch until you have a powerful closure.

_partlyCorrect.final: Keep refining your pitch until you have a powerful closure.
_partlyCorrect.notFinal: Keep refining your pitch until you have a powerful closure.

title: Text
body: How well have you used the Six C's in your pitch? Rate yourself on the sliding scales below.

_events.text: Don't forget, the tool you need is in the design folio!

You’re a designer now so go and solve more problems to make the world better. Use your design thinking skills over and over again. You can always check in with me and go through these stages anytime you like. Good luck, designer. I’m proud of you!

title: Who is Dee?
body: Dee is our design thinking coach and is the voice of the instructor throughout the stages of learning. Dee is also a voice in the design folio, guiding students to self-facilitate their learning either individually or in teams. Scroll down to learn more about the design folio.

_events.text: Hi, Dee here! I’m going to be your design thinking coach. Just like a sport coach helps to make athletes stronger, I can make you stronger in creativity and problem solving. You'll have to work hard and work together with your peers. Are you ready?

title: Text
body: Read through the text and type in the missing words.

title: Fill in the Blanks
textBlock:
Empathy is a really important part of design thinking because design is all about %?% and putting humans at the %?% of design.

Having empathy is a key ingredient to becoming the %?% person you can be.

_feedback.correct: Awesome work! You are well on your way to developing your understanding of the empathy stage.

_incorrect.final: Not quite! Read through the text again and then have another go. You can also watch the animation again for some more hints.
_incorrect.notFinal: Not quite! Read through the text again and then have another go. You can also watch the animation again for some more hints.

_partlyCorrect.final: Not quite! Read through the text again and then have another go. You can also watch the animation again for some more hints!.
_partlyCorrect.notFinal: Not quite! Read through the text again and then have another go. You can also watch the animation again for some more hints.

title: Text
body: Read through the text and type in the missing words.

_events.text: We’ve given you one example but you should do as many as you can until you land on a problem you feel really excited about solving.

title: Text
body:
Think of something you think is really clever or a great invention. It might be something digital or something handy.

Consider these questions:

  • What makes this invention so great?
  • Do you know what problem it solves?
  • In what way/s does it make life easier or better?

_items.title: Problem statement
_items.body: The problem is there’s no way to self-guide the first day of school.

_items.title: Question
_items.body: How might we assist new people to our school design their own great first day?

_events.text: A successful prototype doesn’t only look good but it serves the right purpose. Don’t just choose to build something because you like to play with Lego. Choose a prototype to best demonstrate the idea.

_transcript.inlineTranscriptBody:
Design thinking is a way to approach solving complex problems. The design thinking process starts by giving everyone experiencing the problem a chance to be heard. Therefore empathising is at the heart of design thinking. The other stages are define, ideate, prototype and test. These stages generally follow each other and also work in back-and-forth feedback loops. You will need patience, grit, empathy and creativity to collaborate well, try lots of ideas, and communicate them. Design thinking brings our head, heart and hands together to find innovative solutions to complex problems. [Design thinking begins with: Empathise].

End of transcript.

Empathy is the work you do to understand someone else’s situation. It’s at the heart of design thinking. Empathy guides all aspects of the process because design thinking is used to solve messy problems that affect lots of people. The empathise stage is where you work to experience someone else’s problem, to understand the way they do things and why, their needs, how they think about the world, and what is meaningful to them. In order to design solutions for someone you must know who they are and what is important to them. The insights you gain can lead you to innovative solutions but recognising insights is harder than you think. Empathy lets us see a problem from different points of view and it makes your solutions better. When you start drawing conclusions from your empathising you are moving into the define stage. [Design thinking continues in: Define].

End of transcript.

The test stage is where you go into more depth developing a viable prototype. Choose one or two of your solutions and test them more thoroughly. Testing gives you more engagement and feedback to refine solutions and learn more about your users. It helps hone your problem statement, refine your prototype and ideas, and make your user part of the creation process. Testing and prototyping are both iterative processes which means you cycle through them multiple times. Think of the test stage as working in parallel to the prototype stage rather than as the next step. When you prototype you’re looking for what works but when you test you’re looking for where your solution fails. Every failure is an opportunity to improve your design so you can prototype and try again. [Thanks for watching Design thinking]. 

End of transcript.

title: Text
body:
Look out for this image throughout the resource. It is a reminder to use your design folio to:

  • take notes
  • remember ideas
  • capture feedback
  • complete additional tasks to extend your understanding of design thinking.

Always click on the image to reveal the task.

_transcript.inlineTranscriptBody:
The define stage is about using what you learned in the empathise stage to define the problem. There is never only one way to define a problem and you will revise your problem statement many times using the empathy insights that are at the heart of design thinking. Start from a particular point of view then figure out what is needed for a solution to be correct from that point of view. This is called framing the problem. The clearer your definition of the problem, the more valuable your solution will be. In the define stage the quality of the ideas you come up with will depend on how you frame the problem, what you choose to focus on and what you choose to ignore. You use this stage to look at lots of possible ways to think of the problem before you agree on one problem statement that you will use in the next stage. You need to explore a variety of problem statements to find one that sparks further exploration and inspires creative ways of solving it. Frame the problem in many different ways, then pick one and ideate! [Design thinking continues in: Ideate].

End of transcript.

The ideate stage is where we imagine, create and express ideas about solutions to the problem we just defined. It’s like brainstorming but broader. While you can work alone, a diverse group of people will produce much better results. You will generate more ideas and they can go in lots of different directions as you build on each other’s efforts. Think widely. Set targets. Switch between coming up with ideas on your own and as a group. Suspend all judgement and include everything. Try finding another question to ask or impose limits to spark new ideas. Think differently. Make sure everyone is contributing and every idea is heard. Ask someone from outside the group to review your ideas. Try to take another point of view and see how that changes the ideas you come up with. Think differently and widely. Mash ideas together to get a new one or pick a random object and ask how that could be a solution. Once you have some ideas it’s time to prototype. [Design thinking continues in: Prototype].

End of transcript.

In the prototype stage you will take two or three of the most popular solutions from your work in the ideate stage and explore them. Using many ideas keeps innovation possible. A prototype is an early model built to test an idea. When you prototype you think with your hands or you make to think. This stage is all about experimenting. You are looking for the best solution to each of the problems you have selected. Prototypes can be anything that helps you test an idea. Ask people to play and engage with your prototype and get feedback about their experience. You might prototype with a wall of post-it notes, a gadget you put together, a role-playing activity, an object, a storyboard, or a physical environment. Keep your prototypes cheap and simple. Expect to fail quickly and often so you can try different options without committing to one idea. The prototype stage is a chance to talk with users, get new ideas and prepare to test your solutions. [Design thinking continues in: Test].

End of transcript.

_events.text: A great way to ask for feedback is simply to ask users to pinpoint one thing you got right, one thing you got wrong and one thing they wish you’d consider to make it better.

title: Text
body: Select the flipcards to learn more about each stage of design thinking.

title: Text
body:
By learning about design thinking, together we will:

  • get to know a handy tool for solving problems
  • try out new skills and use the process to solve problems, big and small
  • understand more about how people use design to solve problems.

title: 1.1 Weird words
body:
Check out the design folio image on the right. Remember that this indicates that there is an activity to be completed in your design folio.

Select the image to find out more about the activity.

frontImage.alt: Select the image to reveal the design folio task.

_items.backBody:
Why do you think empathy is an important part of the design process?

Add your insights to your design folio.

frontImage.alt: Select the image to reveal the design folio task.

_items.backBody:
Now is the time to decide what problem you want to work on. Choose either:

  • designing the best first day of school

OR

  • another problem that you have identified.

Use your empathy skills to deeply understand the challenges for the people who are impacted by that problem.

frontImage.alt: Select the image to reveal the design folio task.

_items.backBody:
In your design folio, reflect on:

  • three things that have stuck with you
  • three new ideas that you now have
  • what you are most curious about.

frontImage.alt: Select the image to reveal the design folio task.

_items.backBody:
It's time to decide on a final question. 

Don't forget to record this in your design folio.

frontImage.alt: Select the image to reveal the design folio task.

_items.backBody: Record these ideas in your learning folio.

frontImage.alt: Select the image to reveal the design folio task.

_items.backBody: Consider your top three ideas and map them on the matrix against effort and impact. You can find the matrix in your design folio.

frontImage.alt: Select the image to reveal the design folio task.

_items.backBody: Ask others to provide feedback to assist you with creating the best product or service ever! Record their responses in your design folio.

frontImage.alt: Select the image to reveal the design folio task.

_items.backBody:
In your design folio, you’ll find a pitch canvas.

  • Answer the five key questions.
  • Test your pitch with others.

frontImage.alt: Select the image to reveal the design folio task.

_items.backBody: In your design folio, answer the key questions to create a test for your solutions.

frontImage.alt: empathise title card

_items.backBody:
This stage is about:

  • being caring and curious
  • asking questions to know more.

frontImage.alt: Select the image to reveal the design folio task.

_items.backTitle: Getting started with your design folio
_items.backBody:
Ensure that you are signed into your Google account.

Then, open your design folio and:

  • type your name on the title page
  • learn more about how Dee can help you
  • discover some of the digital tools you can use when working in your design folio.

frontImage.alt: Select the image to reveal the design folio task.

_items.backBody: In your design folio, brainstorm and record other designs that Doug could use for the MRI machine.

frontImage.alt: Select the image to reveal the design folio task.

_items.backBody:
In your design folio, record key information about your first day of school:

  • what you did
  • what you felt
  • what you learned.

Use the questions in the folio to guide your thinking.

title: Responsive IFrame
body: There are many ways in which you can practice empathy. Like most things, the more you practice, the better you usually get.

_events.text: This information is really important when engaging with the design thinking process. Check out the learning intentions below.

frontImage.alt: Select the image to reveal the design folio task.

_items.backBody:
Practise using the five whys by interviewing three different people. Remember to:

  • ask one big question
  • ask why again and again (5 times!)
  • record their responses in your design folio.

title: Multiple Choice Question
body:
Select the correct option/s below.

Design thinking is all about using your:

_feedback.correct: Correct! We need to use all these things.

_incorrect.final: Not quite! Think of all the things that design thinking requires you to use.
_incorrect.notFinal: Not quite! Think of all the things that design thinking requires you to use.

_partlyCorrect.final: Not quite! Think of all the things that design thinking requires you to use.
_partlyCorrect.notFinal: Not quite! Think of all the things that design thinking requires you to use.

_events.text: This information is really helpful as you move through this stage of the design thinking process. Check out the learning intentions below.

title: The five whys - problem edition
body: The first thing we need to do it get tough on that problem. Pretend that the worst case scenario is the reality.

_items.title: Example scenario
_items.body: You might be thinking about litter in your school. We know that most people do the right thing but if we are really wanting to solve the problem for everyone, we have to assume it’s a big mess!

_items.title: Phrasing it as a problem
_items.body:
We might phrase the problem as:

  • waste isn’t disposed of properly at our school.

title: Multiple Choice Question
body:
Select the correct response below to complete the statement.

We are:

_items.text: kind on people, tough on problems
tough on people, kind on problems.

_feedback.correct: This is correct, even though it might be uncomfortable being so harsh.

_incorrect.final: Not quite! Think about the purpose of the define stage.
_incorrect.notFinal: Not quite! Think about the purpose of the define stage.

_partlyCorrect.final: Not quite! Think about the purpose of the define stage.
_partlyCorrect.notFinal: Not quite! Think about the purpose of the define stage.

_events.text: This information is really helpful as you move through this stage of the design thinking process. Check out the learning intentions below.

title: Matching Question
body: Match the correct question examples.

_options.text: How much time, energy and money will this idea need?
How much will this solve the problem or change people’s lives?
How much time, energy and money will this idea need?
How much will this solve the problem or change people’s lives?

_feedback.correct: Correct! The best ideas are high impact, minimal effort.

title: Text
body: Read through the text and type or select the missing words.

_events.text: This information is really helpful as you move through this stage of the design thinking process. Check out the learning intentions below.

frontImage.alt: Select the image to reveal the design folio task.

_items.backBody:
Use the prototyping toolkit in your design folio to start planning your prototype. 

The toolkit consists of:

  • space to draw your ideas
  • a sketch pad to plan in more detail
  • a storyboard template, and an example to get you started.

title: Accordion
body: Check out the questions below to refine your choices.

_items.title: What do you want to know?
_items.body:
Choose a few questions you want answered.

If you want to test out whether the weight of your product is acceptable and usable, consider building a rough prototype with the same weight as that of the final product.

If you want to test how the user feels, you may want to use role-playing instead.

_items.title: What prototype makes sense?
_items.body:
Think about the kind of prototype that makes the most sense and gives you the best feedback.

You want to spend more time explaining the idea than the prototype itself!

_items.title: Dive in!
_items.body:
Don’t spend too much time deciding on what to build and how to build it — just go out there and try it!

If you are not sure about what kind of prototype to use, make a few and test them.

Your first few prototypes may be failures, but that’s okay, done is better than perfect!

title: checking in
body: How well are you using your:

_items.title: heart?
_items.body: Have you connected with people and are they still at the centre of what you are doing?

_items.title: head?
_items.body: How well are you using your head to think of clever ideas to make life better for people?

_items.title: hands?
_items.body: How are you using your hands to create models and test out your ideas?

title: Text
body:
In the next stage, the focus will be on:

  • learning how to pitch like a pro
  • communicating ideas for maximum impact.

title: Text
body: Read through the text and type or select the missing words.

_events.text: This information is really helpful as you move through this final stage. Check out the learning intentions below.

title: My pitch is consistent
body:
• Your team needs to be on the same page
  • Learn the facts and figures and have a consistent mantra or tag line.

_feedback.correct: Nice work! Consistency ensures that everyone has the same message.

_incorrect.final: Keep practising! Remember you need to get everyone on the same page.
_incorrect.notFinal: Keep practising! Remember you need to get everyone on the same page.

_partlyCorrect.final: Keep practising! Remember you need to get everyone on the same page.
_partlyCorrect.notFinal: Keep practising! Remember you need to get everyone on the same page.

title: My pitch is compelling
body:
• Make it interesting
  • Tell a story
  • Throw in some stats
  • Make people want more!

_feedback.correct: Fantastic work in making people want more!

_incorrect.final: Think about an interesting story that you could include.
_incorrect.notFinal: Think about an interesting story that you could include.

_partlyCorrect.final: Think about an interesting story that you could include.
_partlyCorrect.notFinal: Think about an interesting story that you could include.

title: My pitch is credible
body:
• Own the space, don't apologise for taking the stage
  • Be the most confident person in the room.

_feedback.correct: Your confidence will help to convince others that you have the best solution.

_incorrect.final: Don't be afraid to let your confidence shine through. Own that stage!
_incorrect.notFinal: Don't be afraid to let your confidence shine through. Own that stage!

_partlyCorrect.final: Don't be afraid to let your confidence shine through. Own that stage!
_partlyCorrect.notFinal: Don't be afraid to let your confidence shine through. Own that stage!

title: Text
body:
It is important to create a plan for how, when, where and with whom you're testing your idea with.

It is also beneficial to decide on what success looks like and what failure looks like. As much as we don't like to fail, remember that every failure is an opportunity to improve your design.

_events.text: All of this information is super important when engaging with the design thinking process. Check out the learning intentions below.
You will see me throughout this resource and I also appear in the design folio.

_items.title: The order of the design thinking process
_items.body: Although the design thinking process isn’t strictly linear, we have designed these learning stages to be completed in a linear form for first time design thinkers.

_items.title: Assessment suggestions
_items.body:
The best way to set and gauge assessment for these learning stages is through the design folio. Teachers can use the tasks in the design folio for differentiating the learning experience for their students.

You may also like to set a contextual challenge for your class or school and have a panel-style vote for the most plausible design. Students can peer assess each other’s ideas and you can even invite members of the community in for assessment of ideas.

_items.title: Collaboration
_items.body:
Design thinking is a collaborative task, so setting the right environment for this is ideal. Consider clustering desks and providing spaces for breakout conversations or individual reflection.

Some protocols including building on the ideas of others and creating an optimistic supportive space are a great way to get your class on the same page.

_graphic.alt: Dee, the post it note character who appears throughout the resource to guide the learner.

title: Text
body: The Six C's is a great strategy to use when engaging in the design thinking process.

_items.title: Time
_items.body: It is anticipated that this module will take approximately 60 minutes to complete.

_items.title: Resources
_items.body:
• Student access to this resource
  • design folio.

_items.title: Learning intentions and success criteria
_items.body:
Learning intentions

Through having some fun in learning how to ‘get to the point’, together we will:

  • practice how to create ‘How might we…?’ questions
  • get clear on a great challenge worth designing a solution for
  • focus on things that are ‘un-Googleable’.

Success criteria

You will know this session is successful if students can:

  • create clear, strong and solvable (but 'un-Googleable') questions for design
  • attempt to answer their question.

_items.title: Overview of learning experiences
_items.body:
In this stage, learners are getting clarity of the problem and turning it into a 'how might we...' question. In order to have a firm foundation for the rest of the process, students need to look for questions that have a person at the centre and a clear issue to address. For example:

“How might we ensure every new student (person) has the best first day of school (issue) possible so that they feel connected straight away (clear outcome)?”

Explore

  • Fill in the blank answers: heart; problem; time; money; resources; defining; solve.

Experience

  • Use the clip to reinforce the steps involved in the five whys process. Encourage students to role play some contextual situations using the five whys strategy.

Give it a go

  • True/False answer: kind on people, touch on problems.
  • 3.1 - This template looks slightly different to the five whys template used in the empathy stage, however, it essentially still involves asking the question, 'Why?' five times. There are three copies of this template but more can copies can be created by duplicating the slide.

Check your understanding

  • 3.2 - Model some responses.
  • Ensure that students have a clear understanding of the need for an unGoogleable question. Some examples include:
    • How might we reduce the rubbish in our school playground?
    • How might we transform the library space so that it promotes the use of technology ?
    • How might we create a bush tucker garden to support the community?

Record and reflect

  • 3.3 - Ensure that students have phrased their final question to start with 'How might we...?'
  • 3.4 - Individual reflection activity.

_items.title: Scaling the project
_items.body:
Class

  • Students work in small groups or independently on defining the issue associated with a poor first day of school experience.

School

  • Students may test out their problem statements with other students and teachers in order to get to a clearly defined statement.

Community

  • Students may conclude there is a distinct issue in their community to be solved by working alongside local community members and conducting a wide range of interview.

_items.title: Time
_items.body: It is anticipated that this module will take approximately 40 minutes to complete.

_items.title: Resources
_items.body:
• Student access to this resource
  • design folio
  • post it notes
  • markers
  • music (or a timer).

_items.title: Learning intentions and success criteria
_items.body:
Learning intentions

Through learning and experiencing how to come up with ideas, together we will:

  • explore lots of perspectives
  • be solutions focused
  • develop skills to help us come up with lots of solutions.

Success criteria

You will know this session is successful if students can:

  • ask for input from others
  • filter down to a small set of strong and challenging ideas
  • demonstrate ambition and creativity.

_items.title: Overview of learning experiences
_items.body:
This stage is about solving the challenge. The room will need to be set up for lots of idea sharing, moving and collaborating. Make sure there are lots of post it notes.

We’ve also set up a task called the six step song sprint, so you will need some music.

Explore

  • Fill in the blank answers: designers; ideas; solutions; innovate.

Experience

  • Ensure that students click on each of the images to reveal the information.

Give it a go

  • Students will need access to post it notes and music (or a timer). Encourage students to continually build on the ideas of their peers'.
  • 4.1 - Encourage students to utilise different digital tools to record their ideas. Some suggestions of tools can be found in the design folio.

Check your understanding

  • Encourage students to continually improve their application of the ideation rules.

Record and reflect

  • Matching activity answers: Effort = How much time, energy and money will this idea need?; Impact = How much will this solve the problem or change people's lives? 
  • 4.2 - Students could map this out using post it notes.
  • 4.3 - Individual reflection activity.

_items.title: Scaling the project
_items.body:
Class

  • You may ask students to ‘speed date’ their HMW question to get a quantity of ideas, particularly if they are working solo.

School

  • You may allow students a week to get as many ideas as they can by setting their HMW question challenge for investigation. Can they get 100 ideas in one week?

Community

  • Students may hold a rapid ideation session and also look to place some restraints on their HMW, for example, ask students if they could solve the problem in 2 week, or 2 years? What if they had only $20, or if they had $20,000. Would this change the solutions or the way they think about the problem?

_items.title: Time
_items.body: It is anticipated that this module will take approximately 55 minutes to complete.

_items.title: Resources
_items.body:
• Student access to this resource
  • design folio
  • Lego or building blocks
  • assortment of materials to use to prototype, such as paper, cardboard, sticky tape, fabric, plastic piping, etc.

_items.title: Learning intentions and success criteria
_items.body:
Learning intentions

Through making a prototype, together we will:

  • develop skills in tinkering and creativity
  • learn how to give and receive feedback
  • communicate our idea with others.

Success criteria

You will know this session is successful if students can:

  • build a concept that can be understood by others
  • seek feedback, acting on feedback and making tweaks and changes to their idea or the way they communicate the idea
  • transfer the idea out of their head and into their hands.

_items.title: Overview of learning experiences
_items.body:
The key to learning in this stage is to get tangible. The prototype stage is about taking the idea and turning into something real and sharable. It’s about getting feedback on a model, for example. It’s not the final product, but a working example. This is the stage you want to have lots of ‘things’ for student to use, such as lego, cardboard etc.

Explore

  • Fill in the blank answers: hands; experimenting; ideate; cheap and simple; talk; ideas; test.

Experience

  • Identify other prototypes of familiar products.

Let's explore some more

  • Provide opportunities for students to discuss what skills might be needed for each type of prototyping.

Give it a go

  • 5.1 - Encourage students to be creative.

Check your understanding

  • Students may need some assistance with refining their choices. 
  • 5.2 - The five key questions will assist students to refine their thinking.

Record and reflect

  • 5.3 - Discuss the expectations for providing and receiving feedback. Identify ways to collect feedback.
  • 5.4 - Individual reflection activity.

_items.title: Scaling the project
_items.body:
Class

  • A one hour prototype sprint can be a great way to activate brains and bodies towards the end of a week.

School

  • Can you encourage students to co-create a makerspace for the school and prototype from a space such as the library? Prototypes can be on display for a period of time to seek a range of feedback.

Community

  • Encourage a session to invite community into the school, or ask students to find a space in their local area to prototype. Many local community libraries have tinker spaces for hire!

_items.title: Time
_items.body: It is anticipated that this module will take approximately 70 minutes to complete.

_items.title: Resources
_items.body:
• Student access to this resource
  • design folio.

_items.title: Learning intentions and success criteria
_items.body:
Learning intentions

Through building empathy and caring about our problem, together we will:

  • see what failure is and learn from it
  • be ready to try again or celebrate success
  • develop skills in communication.

Success criteria

You will know this session is successful if students can:

  • test their prototype
  • identify what success and fail looks like
  • demonstrate resilience through ensuring they have a viable working idea.

_items.title: Overview of learning experiences
_items.body:
This stage takes student to the next level of their design thinking journey as they put their idea into the real world. They need to decide on what success and fail looks like, and can test part of an idea over and over until they have a viable working idea to take to market.

Explore

  • Fill in the blank answers: viable working solution; engagement; feedback; improve; improve; ideating and prototyping.

Experience

  • Prompt students to identify other products or services that have continued to improve in order to reflect changing demands and expectations.

Explore some more

  • Drag and drop answers: clear; compelling; credible; consistent; conversational; close.

Give it a go

  • Emphasise that the Six C's can assist with guiding and improving a product pitch.
  • 6.1 - Allow students time to practice and refine their pitch.

Check your understanding

  • Encourage students to continually reflect and improve.

Record and reflect

  • 6.2 - Brainstorm ways to capture the testing process.
  • 6.3 - Individual reflection activity.

_items.title: Scaling the project
_items.body:
Class/School/Community

  • Tests can be encouraged across a range of scales, but always level up the process to the next scale! The test stage isn’t always something that comes to fruition either. You may encourage students to head back to an ideation phase or kick on the learning with a whole new problem to solve!

title: Design thinking
body: Design thinking brings our head, heart and hands together to find innovative solutions to complex problems. Empathising is at the heart of design thinking. The other stages are define, ideate, prototype and test. These stages generally follow each other and also work in back-and-forth feedback loops.

_items.title: Time
_items.body: It is anticipated that this module will take approximately 30 minutes to complete.

_items.title: Resources
_items.body:
• Student access to this resource
  • design folio.

_items.title: Learning intentions and success criteria
_items.body:
Learning intentions

Through learning about design thinking, together we will:

  • get to know a handy tool for solving problems
  • try out new skills and use the process to solve problems, big and small
  • understand more about how people use design to solve problems.

Success criteria

You will know this session is successful if students can:

  • identify the main stages of the design thinking process
  • engage with the early stages of a design thinking challenge
  • access and navigate their design folio.

_items.title: Overview of learning experiences
_items.body:
This module is designed as a way for teachers to introduce students to the design thinking process. Teachers are encouraged to work through this module with their students.

Students explore the main stages in the design thinking process and engage in the early stages of a design thinking challenge.

Your design folio

  • Ensure that students are logged into their Google accounts and that they can access the design folio.
  • Explore the first few slides of the design folio together so that students become familiar with the key features. Allow time for students to explore some of the additional tools which can be used to enhance the use of the design folio.
  • Clarify your expectations of how the students are to utilise the design folio and share it with you.

Explore

  • Fill in the blank answers: problems; heart; head; hands; world
  • 1.1 - Refer back to the animation to identify and define new words.
  • Ensure students understand the learning intentions. You may like to display these in the room so that they are visible throughout the session.

Experience

  • Encourage students to share their responses before selecting each of the flipcards.
  • 1.2 - The flipcards can be used to support students with this task.

Give it a go

  • You may like to provide some examples to stimulate brainstorming and discussion, such as the light bulb, wheel and axle, GPS, telephone, penicillin, YouTube, 3D printer, XBox, etc. You could also specify a particular invention field, such as gadgets, architecture, food, fashion, health, sport, sustainability, transportation, entertainment etc. 
  • 1.3 - Can be completed individually or in groups.

Lets explore some more

  • Use this story to emphasise that inventions often solve more than one problem. 
  • 1.4 - Encourage students to use their online research skills to identify other MRI (or similar) designs.

Check your understanding

  • Drag and drop answers: pink hexagon; green hexagon; yellow hexagon; purple hexagon; blue hexagon.
  • 1.5 - Allow time for students to share their individual responses as this information is needed to guide the next stage in the design process.

Record and reflect

  • 1.6 - This is an individual reflection activity. This same reflection template features at the end of each stage.

What's next?

  • Ensure students know where their design folio has been saved and that they can access it through their Google Drive.

_items.title: Scaling the project
_items.body:
This is a good time to decide the scale of this project. It may be a:

  • class based project
  • project which extends across the school
  • project which addresses a community issue.

_items.title: Time
_items.body: It is anticipated that this module will take approximately 30 minutes to complete.

_items.title: Resources
_items.body:
• Student access to this resource
  • design folio.

_items.title: Learning intentions and success criteria
_items.body:
Learning intentions

Through building empathy and caring about our problem, together we will:

  • see a range of perspectives different to our own
  • ask questions to gain insights
  • practice understanding.

Success criteria

You will know this session is successful if students can:

  • demonstrate curiosity about others' viewpoints
  • ask interesting questions
  • identify problems to solve in their local context
  • engage in conversations about people
  • begin to wrestle with a big problem to solve.

_items.title: Overview of learning experiences
_items.body:
In this stage, students experience a case study of a hospital in America and work on developing their skills to understand others' points of view. They experiment with using the five whys strategy to think more deeply about a problem.

Explore

  • Fill in the blank answers: people; centre; best.
  • Drag and drop answers: listening; asking; learning; showing concern; paying attention; getting to know.
  • Ensure students understand the learning intentions. You may like to display these in the room so that they are visible throughout the session.

Experience

  • Watch and discuss the clip, encouraging students to identify times when they have demonstrated empathy or experienced others demonstrating empathy towards them.
  • 2.1 - Prompt students to provide some specific examples or experiences. 

Give it a go

  • Emphasise that the five whys is just as the name suggests: asking one big question, and then asking 'why?' five times. It is a good strategy to get clarity on a problem to support someone to think deeply about their problem.
  • 2.2 - Model the strategy using the first template and/or duplicate the slide to make additional copies of the template if you want the students to interview more people.

Check your understanding

  • Multiple choice answers: hands; head; heart.
  • 2.3 - To extend this activity, you might get students to complete this for another peer in the class (ie: How has the peer demonstrated empathy towards them?)

Record and reflect

  • 2.4 - A decision needs to be made about what problem the students are going to work on.
  • 2.5 - Individual reflection activity.

_items.title: Scaling the project
_items.body:
Class

  • Students self reflect and use think/pair/share strategies to interview each other.

School

  • Students take time to talk in assembly, offer a survey to other year groups or take time with other classes. They may also conduct playground observations.

Community

  • Provide a period of time post the learning stage completion for students to embed and activate the learning. For example, a week to gain insights from their family, sporting or broader school community groups.

_events.text: Every great designer keeps a folio to capture a process coming to life, collect inspiration and ideas, and reflect on learning and growth. There’s a handy digital design folio that we’ve created for you.

frontImage.alt: Select the image to reveal the design folio task.

_items.backBody:
In your design folio:

  • think of your invention
  • draw it or find an image of it
  • convince as many people as you can that it's the best invention ever.

frontImage.alt: prototype title card

_items.backBody:
This stage is all about:

  • the idea of 'don't tell me, show me!'
  • making ideas come to life through creating.

frontImage.alt: Select the image to reveal the design folio task.

_items.backBody:
In your design folio, practice this skill using:

  • the design challenge we started to work on about designing the best first day of school

OR

  • your own problem.

frontImage.alt: Select the image to reveal the design folio task.

_items.backBody:
In your design folio, reflect on:

  • three things that have stuck with you
  • three new ideas that you now have
  • what you are most curious about.

frontImage.alt: Select the image to reveal the design folio task.

_items.backBody:
In your design folio, reflect on how empathetic you are. Think about:

  • how you demonstrate understanding for others
  • some specific examples of situations when you have shown empathy.

frontImage.alt: slice of bread with 100s and 1000s on top

_items.backBody:
You want LOTS of ideas.

Some designers won't leave a room until they have 100 ideas to solve their HMW question.

frontImage.alt: Select the image to reveal the design folio task.

_items.backBody:
In your design folio, reflect on:

  • three things that have stuck with you
  • three new ideas that you now have
  • what you are most curious about.

frontImage.alt: Select the image to reveal the design folio task.

_items.backBody:
In your design folio, reflect on:

  • three things that have stuck with you
  • three new ideas that you now have
  • what you are most curious about.

frontImage.alt: Select the image to reveal the design folio task.

_items.backBody: You are going to encounter new words such as 'ideate' during your design thinking learning journey. Record these words in your design folio and include their definitions.

title: Flipcard
body: Click the image to reveal the task.

frontImage.alt: Select the image to reveal the design folio task.

_items.backBody: This is where the task will appear. Students will be reminded to go to their design folio to complete the task.

frontImage.alt: Select the image to reveal the design folio task.

_items.backBody:
In your design folio, reflect on:

  • three things that have stuck with you
  • three new ideas that you now have
  • what you are most curious about.

title: Text
body:
A good way to understand the process of design thinking is to focus on a design challenge.

A great example is to think about your first day of school. Maybe you can remember your brother or sister's first day. We all had a first day of school, and some of us have had more than one first day.

Understanding what was great and what was challenging is a really important step in this challenge.

frontImage.alt: Select the image to reveal the design folio task.

_items.backBody:
In your design folio, reflect on:

  • three things that have stuck with you
  • three new ideas that you now have
  • what you are most curious about.

_items.title: What are the five whys?
_items.body: The five whys is a good strategy to get clarity on a problem to support someone to think more deeply about their problem. It involves asking the question 'why?' five times.

_items.title: Ask one big question
_items.body:
When you are interviewing a user to understand their point of view, ask one big question and then after they respond, ask 'why?' five times to dig deeper. For example:

  • Ask a question
  • Why? (1st time)
  • Why? (2nd time)
  • Why? (3rd time)
  • Why? (4th time)
  • Why? (5th time).

_items.title: Write down
_items.body: Write down what you hear, paying particular attention to the moments you might find yourself saying ‘Aha! I think I understand now!’

_items.title: Think about
_items.body:
Think about the user's:

  • point of view
  • ways of doing things and why
  • needs
  • ways of thinking about the world
  • values or what is meaningful to them.

frontImage.alt: Select the image to reveal the design folio task.

_items.backTitle: 3.2 Getting to the heart of the problem
_items.backBody:
Turn each of your problem statements into a question. Select three problem statements and make at least three questions to test out.

Record these in your design folio.

title: Step 1
body: Turn each of your problem statements into a question. We can do this by starting our questions with the words, 'How might we...?' You might see this written as HMW.

_items.title: Step 1
_items.body:
• Get your 'How might we...?' question and write it on a sheet of paper.
  • Place it in the middle of a table.

_items.title: Step 2
_items.body: • Stand with your team around the table, each person with a stack of sticky notes and a pen.

_items.title: Step 3
_items.body: • Choose your favourite song and hit play!

_items.title: Step 4
_items.body: • For the length of the song, say ideas as you write them down and slam them on to the piece of paper with the question. Make sure you share the air and let others say their ideas too!

_items.title: Step 5
_items.body: • When the song finishes, each person needs to push through and think of three more ideas for the pile.

_items.title: Step 6
_items.body: • Sort through and match up ideas. Vote for your favourite three.

title: Text
body:
When coming up with ideas you are looking for the number one, the gold star, the best of the best. You want your idea to have high impact so that it really makes a difference. At the same time, you need to think about how to achieve this high impact while using the following things really efficiently and with minimal effort:

  • time
  • energy
  • resources.

title: Don't tell me, show me!
body:
Feedback is such an important part of the prototype stage.

Harley Earl would have been asking his clients if they liked the shape of the roof or the feel of the door handle. They couldn’t drive the car but he was getting valuable insights about key design features that could mean the difference between the sale of a car or not.

title: Empathise
body: Empathy is at the heart of design thinking. It guides all aspects of the process because design thinking is used to solve messy problems that affect lots of people. The empathise stage is where you work to experience someone else’s problem, to understand the way they do things and why, their needs, how they think about the world, and what is meaningful to them.

title: Define
body: The define stage is about using what you learned in the empathise stage to define the problem. There is never only one way to define a problem but the clearer your definition of the problem, the more valuable your solution will be.

title: Ideate
body: The ideate stage is where we imagine, create and express ideas about solutions to the problem we just defined. It’s like brainstorming but broader. While you can work alone, a diverse group of people will produce much better results. You will generate more ideas and they can go in lots of different directions as you build on each other’s efforts.

title: Prototype
body: The prototype stage is all about experimenting with two or three of the most popular solutions. It is also a chance to talk with users and get new ideas. Prototypes can be anything that helps you test an idea but they should be cheap and simple. Expect to fail quickly and often so you can try different options without committing to one idea.

title: Test
body: The test stage is where you go into more depth developing a viable prototype. Testing gives you more engagement and feedback to refine solutions and learn more about your users. Testing and prototyping are both iterative processes which means you cycle through them multiple times.

title: Accordion
body:
Every designer has a folio of work so we have created a design folio for students too. The design folio is a digital resource designed for students to:

  • capture the process coming to life
  • collect inspiration and ideas
  • reflect on learning and growth.

It’s digital for a reason. We’ve mirrored what happens in industry.

_items.title: Accessing the design folio
_items.body:
Ensure that students are logged into their Google accounts.

Students will only need to click on the design folio link once. This will prompt them to save a copy of the design folio template which they can access from their Google Drive at any time.

If for some reason, you need access to a new template, a copy can be found in the resource section in the top right corner of this page.

_items.title: Stage 2
_items.body:
English

EN2-1A Communicates in a range of informal and formal contexts by adopting a range of roles in group, classroom, school and community contexts.

  • ACELY1687
  • ACELA1488
  • ACELA1476
  • ACELY1688
  • ACELY1792

EN2-10C Thinks imaginatively, creatively and interpretively about information, ideas and texts when responding to and composing texts.

EN2-11D Responds to and composes a range of texts that express viewpoints of the world similar to and different from their own.

  • ACELT1596
  • ACELA1489

EN2-12E Recognises and uses an increasing range of strategies to reflect on their own and others’ learning.

 

Science and Technology

title: DP
body:
We’ve posed a problem you can pick up and run with around the 'best first day'. Everyone had a first day of school either as a student, a parent or a staff member. You might even look at it from the perspective of the school pet or a younger sibling.

It’s a great problem to explore because of the universality and also the range of potential perspectives.

title: Accordion
body:
Here are some suggested resources and classroom setup ideas for small groups or whole class to explore during your teaching. We've provided an overview of the lesson in each stage, plus a way you can differentiate the experience at three scales:

  • class
  • school
  • community.

_items.title: Class
_items.body:
• Apply the design thinking skills to the class group.
  • You may choose to follow our ‘best first day’ question to keep the focus on the process and allow students to self-drive the learning.

_items.title: School
_items.body:
• Skills are encouraged to be applied across the school, with students testing ideas with other students and teachers.
  • Students are asked a school-based question and are provided with opportunities to present their projects to different audiences.

_items.title: Community
_items.body:
• This involves a deep dive.
  • You may choose to allow students to do in depth investigation and come up with their own problems.
  • A unit of Project Based Learning (PBL) work may even be created to allow students to test and trial their skills.

_items.title: Some example questions to get you started
_items.body:
The possibilities are endless, but some 'How might we...' questions to get you started include:

  • How might we reduce the rubbish in our school playground?
  • How might we transform the library space so that it promotes the use of technology?
  • How might we create a bush tucker garden to support the community?

title: DP
body:
At the same time, this resource is written so that you can apply it to solving your own design thinking challenge.

Think about how you could integrate this resource into:

  • a learning area or topic currently being studied in your class
  • your current context.

_transcript.inlineTranscriptBody:
Design thinking is a way to approach solving complex problems. The design thinking process starts by giving everyone experiencing the problem a chance to be heard. Therefore empathising is at the heart of design thinking. The other stages are define, ideate, prototype and test. These stages generally follow each other and also work in back-and-forth feedback loops. You will need patience, grit, empathy and creativity to collaborate well, try lots of ideas, and communicate them. Design thinking brings our head, heart and hands together to find innovative solutions to complex problems. [Design thinking begins with: Empathise].

End of transcript.

Empathy is the work you do to understand someone else’s situation. It’s at the heart of design thinking. Empathy guides all aspects of the process because design thinking is used to solve messy problems that affect lots of people. The empathise stage is where you work to experience someone else’s problem, to understand the way they do things and why, their needs, how they think about the world, and what is meaningful to them. In order to design solutions for someone you must know who they are and what is important to them. The insights you gain can lead you to innovative solutions but recognising insights is harder than you think. Empathy lets us see a problem from different points of view and it makes your solutions better. When you start drawing conclusions from your empathising you are moving into the define stage. [Design thinking continues in: Define].

End of transcript.

The define stage is about using what you learned in the empathise stage to define the problem. There is never only one way to define a problem and you will revise your problem statement many times using the empathy insights that are at the heart of design thinking. Start from a particular point of view then figure out what is needed for a solution to be correct from that point of view. This is called framing the problem. The clearer your definition of the problem, the more valuable your solution will be. In the define stage the quality of the ideas you come up with will depend on how you frame the problem, what you choose to focus on and what you choose to ignore. You use this stage to look at lots of possible ways to think of the problem before you agree on one problem statement that you will use in the next stage. You need to explore a variety of problem statements to find one that sparks further exploration and inspires creative ways of solving it. Frame the problem in many different ways, then pick one and ideate! [Design thinking continues in: Ideate].

End of transcript.

The ideate stage is where we imagine, create and express ideas about solutions to the problem we just defined. It’s like brainstorming but broader. While you can work alone, a diverse group of people will produce much better results. You will generate more ideas and they can go in lots of different directions as you build on each other’s efforts. Think widely. Set targets. Switch between coming up with ideas on your own and as a group. Suspend all judgement and include everything. Try finding another question to ask or impose limits to spark new ideas. Think differently. Make sure everyone is contributing and every idea is heard. Ask someone from outside the group to review your ideas. Try to take another point of view and see how that changes the ideas you come up with. Think differently and widely. Mash ideas together to get a new one or pick a random object and ask how that could be a solution. Once you have some ideas it’s time to prototype. [Design thinking continues in: Prototype].

End of transcript.

In the prototype stage you will take two or three of the most popular solutions from your work in the ideate stage and explore them. Using many ideas keeps innovation possible. A prototype is an early model built to test an idea. When you prototype you think with your hands or you make to think. This stage is all about experimenting. You are looking for the best solution to each of the problems you have selected. Prototypes can be anything that helps you test an idea. Ask people to play and engage with your prototype and get feedback about their experience. You might prototype with a wall of post-it notes, a gadget you put together, a role-playing activity, an object, a storyboard, or a physical environment. Keep your prototypes cheap and simple. Expect to fail quickly and often so you can try different options without committing to one idea. The prototype stage is a chance to talk with users, get new ideas and prepare to test your solutions. [Design thinking continues in: Test].

End of transcript.

The test stage is where you go into more depth developing a viable prototype. Choose one or two of your solutions and test them more thoroughly. Testing gives you more engagement and feedback to refine solutions and learn more about your users. It helps hone your problem statement, refine your prototype and ideas, and make your user part of the creation process. Testing and prototyping are both iterative processes which means you cycle through them multiple times. Think of the test stage as working in parallel to the prototype stage rather than as the next step. When you prototype you’re looking for what works but when you test you’re looking for where your solution fails. Every failure is an opportunity to improve your design so you can prototype and try again. [Thanks for watching Design thinking].

End of transcript.

title: Accordion
body: Watch Radiology at Children's Hospital (YouTube 4:34) which highlights how design thinking was used to improve a medical process for children in hospital.

_items.title: What was the problem?
_items.body:
Doug, a chief designer at a company called GE, saw the terrible experience that kids had to go through while being scanned in traditional Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) machines.

In fact, about 80% of kids had to be sedated during their scan! Sedation is when a doctor gives a patient some type of medication to calm or relax them.

_items.title: What was done?
_items.body:
Doug created Pirate Island Adventure by making the scanner look like a pirate ship.

The entire MRI experience became like ‘playtime’ for kids.

_items.title: What was the outcome?
_items.body:
Kids loved the new experience and quite a few of them actually wanted to keep coming back!

Parents were also relieved.

Sedation rate dropped from 80% to 10% which meant that hospitals benefited too.

title: Video
body: What are the Five Whys? (YouTube 2:08) explains how the five whys can be used to turn ideas into action.

title: Video
body: There are many ways that you can gain empathy. Watch Stages of Design Thinking (YouTube 2:29) to explore some examples of how the staff at a hospital innovation lab in America are gaining empathy, and also having fun whilst doing it!

_items.backTitle: 5.2 Deciding on a prototype - five keys questions
_items.backBody: In your design folio, answer the five key questions to help you decide on a protoype to move forward with.

frontImage.alt: Select the image to reveal the design folio task.

_items.backBody: In your design folio, record what you already know about the different stages of the design thinking process.
